title: 109_hr4766
content:
The "Esther Martinez Native American Languages Preservation Act of 2006" expands programs to ensure the survival of Native American languages, including Native American language nests providing instruction and child care in a Native American language for young children. The Act expands programs for Native American language preservation, including Native American language nests for young children and Native American language survival schools for school-age students. These programs focus on providing instruction in Native American languages and ensuring their survival. The Act aims to develop instructional courses and materials for learning Native American languages, provide teacher training, and work towards all students achieving proficiency in these languages. The Act focuses on fluency in a Native American language and academic proficiency in mathematics, reading, and science. Native American language restoration programs aim to increase proficiency and fluency in at least one Native American language through educational programs located in areas with high numbers of Native American students. These programs provide training for teachers, develop instructional materials, and offer instruction in Native American languages. Native American language programs focus on immersion, culture camps, coordination with educational entities, universities, colleges, master-apprentice learning, and regional programs. Teacher training includes translation for fluent speakers. The development of Native American language materials, including books, audio and visual tools, and interactive media programs, is a key focus of language programs. Training programs are also provided for Native American language teachers and teachers in schools to effectively utilize these materials for teaching. In subsection (c), amendments are made to paragraphs (5) and (6), and a new paragraph (7) is added requiring applicants for grants related to Native American language education to have at least 3 years of relevant experience. Additionally, subsection (e)(2) specifies that grants for purposes in subsection (b)(7) are limited to a 3-year basis. SEC. 3. DEFINITION.
    Section 815 of the Native American Programs Act of 1974 is amended to define "average" as the total hours of Native American language instruction divided by the total number of students in an immersion program.
SEC. 4. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR PROGRAM TO ENSURE THE SURVIVAL AND CONTINUING VITALITY OF NATIVE AMERICAN LANGUAGES.
    Section 816(e) is amended to change the years for appropriations from 1999-2002 to 2008-2012. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
